The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the: 1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter. 2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body. 3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body. 4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. explanation: No for statements are present in the provided function. MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 applies specifically to for loops (their three clauses and loop-counter/loop-control-flag usage). The code contains a while loop (while (NULL != (de = readdir (dir)))) and other statements (assignments, function calls, realloc, snprintf, stat, closedir, and an rdc->off increment), but none are for statements with the three clauses governed by Rule 14.2. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 14.2.
